docs.lead_paragraph: Several House Democrats on Thursday chafed at President Obama's insistence that the final version of major health care legislation include a Senate proposal for a new tax on high-cost, employer-sponsored insurance policies.

headline.main: House Democrats Push Back on Cadillac Tax

docs.abstract: Despite the president's endorsement, many House Democrats still dislike the excise tax on so-called Cadillac health plans.
docs.snippet: Despite the president's endorsement, many House Democrats still dislike the excise tax on so-called Cadillac health plans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, has been under fire in recent days for winning some plum provisions for his home state in exchange for voting for his party's big health care legislation. But in a statement on Thursday, Mr. Nelson said he would fight for all states to get the same benefits as Nebraska - a move that some Senate colleagues had predicted as inevitable.

headline.main: Nelson to Fight for All States

docs.abstract: Under fire over his success in winning plum provisions for Nebraska, Senator Ben Nelson said Thursday he would fight for all states to get the same federal Medicaid benefits as his home state.
docs.snippet: Under fire over his success in winning plum provisions for Nebraska, Senator Ben Nelson said Thursday he would fight for all states to get the same federal Medicaid benefits as his home state.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama apparently has embraced the so-called Cadillac tax, an excise tax on high-priced health insurance plans, urging its inclusion in the final health care legislation to be hammered out between Democratic leaders in the House and Senate.

headline.main: What Counts Toward the Cadillac Tax

docs.abstract: Hitting the threshold for the Senate's proposed excise tax may be easier than you think.
docs.snippet: Hitting the threshold for the Senate's proposed excise tax may be easier than you think.

docs.lead_paragraph: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
docs.abstract: Tips for avoiding high mobile phone charges when traveling internationally, a new push to tax high-cost insurance plans and other consumer-focused items from Thursday's Times.
docs.snippet: Tips for avoiding high mobile phone charges when traveling internationally, a new push to tax high-cost insurance plans and other consumer-focused items from Thursday's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama told House Democratic leaders at a meeting on Wednesday that they should include a tax on high-priced insurance policies favored by the Senate in the final version of far-reaching health care legislation, aides said.

headline.main: Obama Urges Excise Tax on High-Cost Insurance

docs.abstract: President Obama told House Democratic leaders at a meeting on Wednesday that they should include a tax on high-priced insurance policies favored by the Senate in the final version of health care legislation, aides said.
docs.snippet: President Obama told House Democratic leaders at a meeting on Wednesday that they should include a tax on high-priced insurance policies favored by the Senate in the final version of health care legislation, aides said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Symetra Financial, the life insurance company, set the terms of its initial public offering on Wednesday, lowering the overall value of the deal from its October filing and signaling that it was likely to price soon.

headline.main: Symetra Sets I.P.O. Terms, Buffett to Keep Shares

docs.abstract: Symetra Financial set the terms of its initial public offering on Wednesday, lowering the overall value of the deal from its October filing and signaling that the life insurance company is likely to price soon.
docs.snippet: Symetra Financial set the terms of its initial public offering on Wednesday, lowering the overall value of the deal from its October filing and signaling that the life insurance company is likely to price soon.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a bid to create jobs and bolster New York's position as a financial center, Gov. David A. Paterson announced plans on Wednesday to create an international insurance exchange, modeled after Lloyd's of London.

headline.main: New York to Create Global Insurance Exchange

docs.abstract: In a bid to create jobs and bolster New York's position as a financial center, Gov. David A. Paterson announced plans on Wednesday to create an international insurance exchange, modeled after Lloyd's of London.
docs.snippet: In a bid to create jobs and bolster New York's position as a financial center, Gov. David A. Paterson announced plans on Wednesday to create an international insurance exchange, modeled after Lloyd's of London.

docs.lead_paragraph: After a brief hiatus, the television advertising wars over health care have resumed.
docs.abstract: Opponents of a health care overhaul are running more or less the same message as before the Senate passed its legislation on Dec. 24, while supporters appear to be opening a new front.
docs.snippet: Opponents of a health care overhaul are running more or less the same message as before the Senate passed its legislation on Dec. 24, while supporters appear to be opening a new front.

docs.lead_paragraph: Telemedicine has the potential to improve care, but many doctors fear it will jeopardize the doctor-patient bond.

headline.main: Are Doctors Ready for Virtual Visits?
headline.print_headline: Are Doctors Ready for Virtual Visits?

docs.snippet: Telemedicine has the potential to improve care, but many doctors fear it will jeopardize the doctor-patient bond.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was hard to treat Susan Rabinowitz’s cancer because a five-pound tumor had grown unwieldy. But she found a surgeon and help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

headline.seo: Susan Rabinowitz Beat Cancer, but at a Cost
headline.main: Tough Cancer Is Gone, but Not the Bills
headline.print_headline: Tough Cancer Is Gone, but Not the Bills
